I don’t know about you but some styles of music evoke such concrete images in my mind. For example, whenever I listen to almost any song performed by Canadian Jazz singer Diana Krall, I am transported to an environment filled with candlelight or a roaring fire in the hearth, an otherwise darkened room, a glass of wine at the ready and my beloved by my side. We may be dancing cheek to cheek, and, if not that, then, we are certainly side by side, nestled together as young lovers should be. Diana Krall’s music has always been delivered in a velvety smooth manner, sparkling like starlight. Her music style is the antithesis of the frenetic energy of the world of Punk rock that I also enjoy when the mood calls for that. Krall’s Jazz stylings are the musical equivalent of rich chocolate slowly melting in your mouth. She relaxes you with her piano and her voice and makes you feel as though there is no one in the world but you and the one you love and that everything is going to be just fine. It is not without merit that Diana Krall is viewed as being one of the world’s greatest Jazz singers in the past quarter century. She has earned every breathless compliment. This is her story.

Diana Krall was born in 1964, which makes her the exact same age as me. Even though we both qualify now for the senior’s discount at many local stores, she seems to be aging gracefully, while I seem to be happy when I successfully bend down and straighten up again without incident. Diana Krall was born in Nanaimo, British Columbia. Her parents were not professional musicians themselves, but both loved music and filled their family home with the sounds of singing and of piano playing. Diana Krall was drawn toward the piano and began taking formal music lessons through the Royal Conservatory of Music as a preschooler. *(As a personal aside, I once spent a month of my life working as a telephone solicitor for The Royal Conservatory of Music while I lived in London, Ontario. Making cold calls is a tough gig. It isn’t for everyone. Kudos to those who can do it well). In high school, when many kids were forming rock bands, Krall joined the school Jazz band. From there, she began appearing in local coffee houses as a solo artist who sang Jazz standards while patrons poured tips into her jar. In the early 1980s, Diana Krall enrolled in Berklee College of Music in Boston. This was not long after another famous Canadian musician, Bruce Cockburn, had come and gone from Berklee, as well.

Diana Krall released her debut album in 1992. By 1996, she earned her first Grammy nomination for Best Jazz Album of the Year for an album of Nat King Cole classics. In 2000, she toured the world with crooner extraordinaire Tony Bennett. As part of that tour, she and Bennett appeared together on Canadian television on a show hosted by musician Elvis Costello called Spectacle: Elvis Costello With…. That guest appearance was the first step in a relationship that would see Krall and Costello marry in 2003. Not only did they become husband and wife, but they also began a collaborative musical partnership that has seen Costello write lyrics for original music for Krall to record while she has supplied instrumental accompaniment on songs of his. The two remain happily married to this day. In 2006, Diana Krall released an album called The Look of Love. The album title was in reference to a song that was originally written by Burt Bacharach and his musical partner Hal David back in 1967. When this song was initially released, Diana Krall was learning to play the piano in her family home and was only one year away from entering the Royal Conservatory of Music at age 4. In any case, the Bacharach/David composition was first recorded by Jazz legend Stan Getz, but it really gained fame when recorded shortly thereafter by singer Dusty Springfield for inclusion on the soundtrack to the James Bond film Casino Royale. Burt Bacharach and Hal David were nominated for Academy Awards for this song. As for Springfield, she earned herself a Top Twenty hit with it. Flash forward almost a half century later, The Look of Love became a multi -platinum album for Diana Krall. Like Dusty Springfield, Krall’s whispery take on the song brought her into the Top Twenty charts, too. While all of Krall’s albums have sold consistently well throughout her career, The Look of Love is the one that sold the best and really cemented her reputation as a Jazz singer of note around the world. Overall, she has sold over fifteen million records worldwide. She has also earned multiple Grammy and Juno awards, too.

Going to a live concert is a funny experience in many ways. Most concerts that I have attended in person have been raucous affairs that have gotten my heart pumping and my blood flowing. If at the end of the concert I wasn’t soaked in sweat, then I guess I just wasn’t trying hard enough. But not all concerts are the same. A Diana Krall concert is a case in point. Her shows are exercises in class and professional musicianship. I enjoy her live music performances in part because of how crystal clear each note is that emanates from her piano or from the instruments being played by the members of her orchestra. The crispness of these notes in combination with the clarity of each word she sings makes the mellowness of it all almost excruciating to experience, but, in a good way. It is almost too pleasurable, from a music lover’s point of view. The artistry on display from Diana Krall and her orchestra is second to none. I also find her singing style extraordinary as well. The timbre of her voice is so deep and rich, but yet, when she sings, it seems almost completely effortless. I can’t think of another singer….and I know many….who appear so stoic, so completely in control of the muscles in their neck and throat area, as to seem completely still as does Diana Krall when she sings. That lack of muscle contortion when singing seems almost spellbinding in a way. Krall draws you in with her voice, holds your gaze with the calmness of her demeanor as she wrings every drop of emotion from the standards she sings and leaves you spent at the end. If I didn’t know better I would say that she is part siren. I certainly do wish that many of today’s young female singers would take note of how Diana Krall goes about her business. She has an air of sensuality about her that is all breath and body control. There is no need for her to perform half in the nude to cast a spell over her audience. She is the complete package just by being herself.

Having said all of that, I have to admit that Diana Krall’s form of Jazz is something that I have to be in the mood for in order to enjoy. Much of the time, her music moves too slowly for my sensibilities. But then again, there are other times when a good torch song is exactly what the doctor ordered. InAt times like that, Diana Krall is definitely my go-to source. As far as careers go, she has to be very proud of the one that she has created for herself. Right from her earliest days living at home in Nanaimo, B.C., Diana Krall has been all about the music and how it can be used to create feelings of warmth and safety and pleasure for those who hear it. She has made a career out of singing in a style that suits her skill set perfectly. She has toured with the finest musicians in her orchestra and has the most special musical collaborator in the form of her husband, Elvis Costello *(whom she calls Declan when the two of them are at home). All in all, Diana Krall remains one of Canada’s most successful and respected musical acts. I congratulate her on the excellence of her career to date and look forward to her enjoying many more years of success.

I have to say that I am really enjoying my experience learning all about the origins of Jazz music. One of the things that is becoming clear to me along the way is that Jazz music is more than simply a genre of music. It is definitely part of something larger and grander. From everything that I am discovering, the story of Jazz music is completely interwoven with the story of the rise of Black culture in America. The giants of the genre are definitely reflective of the times they found themselves in and are fully deserving of credit for, not only surviving those times but finding ways to thrive and, in doing so, serving to elevate an entire race in the process. A second thing that I am learning is that the story of Jazz is one of important yet, incremental steps. The African rhythms inherent in field songs, marches and dances were combined with the music found in French and Latin cultures in the US South to lay the foundation for what was to become Jazz as we know it. Then came the children of those first freed slaves who traveled about in search of places to call home. In doing so, a new form of music called Ragtime was invented. Ragtime was built on a structure of syncopated rhythms and flourished in bars, honkytonks and brothels where musicians of colour such as Scott Joplin were allowed to play. Today’s post takes us to the next phase in this cultural evolution, the great migration north. This, in turn, will lead us into a discussion of an era that opened the door for the Golden Age of Jazz called The Harlem Renaissance. There are whole books written and university courses taught on the subject of The Harlem Renaissance. My little blog posts will only skim the surface of this historical time but, having said that, I want to stress that the ramifications of what went on during this time period were essential to the formation of Jazz as a music genre and are so culturally important that the impact of The Harlem Renaissance continues to be felt to this very day. While I shall talk about individual musicians, songs, venues and concerts in the posts that follow this one, none would have been possible without The Harlem Renaissance and, specifically for the purposes of today’s post, none would have been possible if not for a bit of musical theatre called Shuffle Along.

Without going into a lot of detail, The Harlem Renaissance truly began when the second generation of freed slaves decided to stop moving about in search of safe places to live in the southern US and instead, opted to settle in one spot to the north. That spot turned out to be in upper Manhattan Island in a place that became known as Harlem. Moving northward seemed the safest bet for these families. The Emancipation Proclamation was only a few decades old when the great migration northward happened. In that time, no societal switch had been flipped which made racial harmony appear as if by magic. Although the laws stated that they were free and equal citizens, the reality was that life remained dangerous for people of colour. It was also a fact that job opportunities were fewer and farther between. Let’s not even get started about the state of public education at the time. Needless to say, staying in the southern states was problematic for many families so, in the hopes of discovering a safer, more tolerant land of opportunity, many opted to journey to the northern states. Some even came all the way to Canada. One of the things that fuelled their dreams was the changing nature of employment in America. The end of WWI coincided with a ramping up of manufacturing and industrialization in the northern states in particular. There were jobs aplenty and not enough people to fill them. So, for the first time in US history, people of colour were actually encouraged/recruited to move north and take on these industrial jobs. As mentioned above, one place that was large enough to accommodate such an influx was Harlem.

As the great migration commenced and people of colour began filing into Harlem, a community of people with similar life experiences and dreams took shape. In due time, members of that community felt the need to develop an official sense of organizational structure that reflected and promoted the needs and aspirations of people of colour. Thus, The National Association for the Advancement of People of Colour (the N.A.A.C.P.) was formed. As part of the NAACP’s mandate, it was felt that developing and establishing the cultural traditions of people of colour was of paramount importance and so, the Arts were given top priority. In this environment, poets such as Langston Hughes came to prominence. Musicians such as Cab Colloway and Duke Ellington became famous. Artists, writers, singers, dancers and composers were all placed at the forefront of a cultural wave whose aim was to give breadth and scope to the lives of people of colour. More than that, the mandate was to promote the idea of people of colour as being human beings worthy of consideration, compassion, equality and respect. It sounds like a logical and obvious thing to aspire to but in the early 1900s, even a gathering spot like Harlem was not a paradise.

When it came to entertainment, the ability of black performers to perform on public stages was still highly regulated. The entertainment industry was primarily controlled by white people for the entertainment pleasure of white audiences. The stories being told on these stages were always shown through the lens of white history and culture. When musicians and entertainers of colour wished to perform, they were either shunted to the sidelines and forced to work in brothels or speakeasys or else, they had to enter the world of white entertainment in ways that were acceptable to white audiences. At the turn of the century, being “acceptable to white audiences” meant that black entertainers had to accept the role of minstrels or jokesters. Blackface makeup was quite common. Many of the songs sung or jokes told all contained elements of subject matter that would be considered highly racist today such as the songs being sung about not being able to tell black people apart. Such songs were openly called “coon” songs and were wildly popular at the time. In such an environment, some people such as Scott Joplin opted to not play along. Instead, he attempted to host his own musicals and to write and perform his own symphonies, in addition to playing his repertoire of Ragtime tunes. While he was able to make a small living by playing in brothels and saloons, he tended to live from week to week and rarely had enough funds available to mount full size stage performances of his highly innovative and original work. Those entertainers of colour who did decide to play the white man’s game did so knowing that self-deprecation and racial submissiveness was the price of admission. It was hard to build a sense of cultural pride when artists were forced to make a public mockery of the very culture they wished to promote.

When the NAACP formed, one of the very first decisions made was to change the way people of colour were presented on the stages of America. It was felt…and rightfully so…that one of the ways to have their stories properly told was to take control of the environment in which plays, musicals and other revues were held. Entering into this scenario was a songwriting pair known as Eubie Blake and Noble Sissle. Blake was the songwriter and Sissle wrote the musical structure. Together the pair had performed for audiences of all races. Often they were the only performers of colour on the particular bill they happened to be part of because there were strict rules in those days that limited stage time to one performer or duo of colour per show. As a result, Blake and Sissle had rarely ever worked with other performers of colour before. That was soon about to change. With the encouragement of those in the NAACP, Blake and Sissle joined forces with another pair of artists known as Flournoy Miller and Aubrey Lyles. Miller and Lyles were a comedy duo and had grown tired of having to put their own race down all of the time in their act. So, they wrote a book called Shuffle Along. This book featured characters who were all people of colour. But what set the story apart for the times was that these characters were not presented as caricatures of black people for the consumption of white audiences. Instead, the characters were presented as intelligent, caring, compassionate, completely self-actualized human beings. The plotline of the story revolved around an election for the mayor of a small town. Never before had a story been written in which people of colour were presented in leadership roles normally reserved for whites. Blake and Sissle were brought in to turn Miller and Lyles’ book into a full-fledged Broadway musical. They did this by reaching into the archive of their own musical material for most of the songs. But they did create three original songs specifically for the play. It is these three songs, two in particular “I’m Just Wild About Harry” and “Love Will FInd a Way”, that helped to elevate Shuffle Along into the realm of one of the most significant and historically important cultural events of all time in America.

Shuffle Along would have been considered to be a significant enough cultural milestone simply based upon the fact that it was the first Broadway musical that featured an all-black cast whose job it was to tell a story uniquely from the perspective of people of colour. This musical was staged in a theatre in which black audiences were permitted to sit in the lower bowl, instead of being forcibly restricted to sitting in the back rows of the upper balcony, which was standard segregationist policy in those days. Shuffle Along helped launch the musical careers of performers such as Adelaide Hall, Josephine Baker, Paul Robeson and Bill “Mr. Bojangles” Robinson. But it was the inclusion of those two afore-mentioned songs that is really important.

In the history of our world, there have been several instances in which genocide has occurred. Genocide is an event in which one socio-demographic group attempts to erase the existence of a second socio-demographic group by enacting systemic policies that often end up leading to mass murder. The Holocaust, the Rwandan Genocide and perhaps, even what is happened in Israel as you read these words, are examples of genocide in action. One of the common methodologies used by the perpetrators of genocide is to de-humanize their victims. One of the ways that this is done is by publicly referring to them in terms that make them seem less than human. Words such as “vermin” and “cockroach” are commonly used by one side to refer to their foes. In this way, it is easier to convince whole masses of people to engage in genocide when their cause is addressed in terms of exterminating vermin, as opposed, to their fellow human beings. When the NAACP formed, they realized that by controlling the narrative of the stories used to describe people of colour, they stood a better chance of creating a picture of an entire race of people who would be recognized for their humanity. Thus, for Shuffle Along, Eubie Blake and Noble Sissle created two songs called “I’m Just Wild About Harry” and “Love Will Find a Way” that showed people of colour enjoying romance FOR THE FIRST TIME EVER ON STAGE!!! I find this absolutely stunning! Loving and being loved is, in my mind, one of the most primal and fundamental aspects of being human. To think that there was a time when society at large didn’t accord people of colour the fundamental right to feel loved is breathtakingly astonishing to me. The creation and inclusion of those two songs was deemed to be such a risky endeavour that Blake and Sissle almost withdrew them from the score. It was only after seeing them performed during dress rehearsals that their importance as a cultural milestone became apparent. Shuffle Along opened in a theatre that was north of the traditional Broadway district but the musical was considered to be part of the Broadway season nonetheless. The show ran for over 500 performances making it the most successful and longest lasting musical of its kind in history at the time. However, years after it ended its run, Shuffle Along was revived in the late 1960s and was nominated for a Tony Award for Best Musical in 1970. But, significantly, what evolved out of the success of Shuffle Along was that it was just as popular with white audiences as it was with black audiences. The crossover nature of its success helped to open the doors for so many other performers of colour to walk through in the decades that followed. When we focus on the likes of Duke Ellington in a future post, we will see how his success was helped in large part by the success of Shuffle Along and how it prepared white audiences for a truer picture of who people of colour were as humans and how amazing so much of their culture actually was.

The Harlem Renaissance lasted until the onset of the Great Depression. To say that it was a golden age for the cultural evolution of people of colour is as big an understatement as I can make. In the weeks to come, we will meet and learn all about some of the kings and queens of the Golden Age of Jazz. Their stories intertwine with those of The Harlem Renaissance. What a time it must have been for those who were there! For many of them, they had grandparents, still living, who had actually been subjected to slavery. To think that in the space of less than half a century, people of colour would be telling their own stories while staging the first all-black Broadway musical. Those must have seemed like heady times, indeed. However, to think that declaring the humanity inherent in an entire race of people was seen as risky and daring says a lot about the world even at that time. Being together in Harlem may have seemed like a more welcoming environment but life was never really easy for people of colour as we shall see in the weeks to come.

Thank you, as always, for reading my words. I write them with deep humility and with much respect for the people involved. I look forward to continuing my learning journey and welcome your presence each step of the way. Take care. I will see everyone again next time on The Story of Jazz for Beginners Like Me.
